ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed skills in rading scientific papers which is an amazing asset to be able to contribute to research in the scientific community.
Foundation in Biochemistry and Biophysics as well as analyzing primary research.
The course significantly improved my skills as a scientific writer and covered a remarkable amount of material fairly quickly.
I acquired general knowledge of biochemistry and learned how to inquire about research papers.
Basic biology and an introduction into reading scientific papers. TA's and mentors were large points of contact and help throughout the course.

I was able to understand the basic concepts of biology, biophysics, and different kinds of molecules found in biology, such as proteins, carbohydrates, etc. I also learned how to properly read and cite scientific papers.
I learned about intro bio!

Being able to apply biological concepts (especially bio-thermodynamics) to real world situations.
Learning how to break down and analyze scientific papers
In addition to learning quite a bit of information about biochemistry and biophysics, including both facts and methods, I learned how to carefully analyze scientific literature.
This course gave me a very solid foundation in biochemistry and biophysics both on a broad scale and also with some compelling and useful case studies to deepen understanding.
intro to biochemical/biophysical concepts

Reading scientific papers, time management not to be cliche but the benchmark project (project completed throughout the term) gave me huge sights to reading primary literature, and exploring a protein in depth was a lot of fun.

Throughout this course, I solidified my ability to find a productive work vs play balance as I needed to space out time spent on the work done for this class while ensuring that it all got done. Academically, I was able to obtain and retain considerable knowledge about the basics of biochemistry and biophysics while enjoying the material every step of the way.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really enjoyed how the lectures had quizzes to help us become motivated to watch the lectures and the lectures were very well put together with the presentations. I also think that the final project instead of a final exam was much more interactive and knowledge provoking. It took a significant amount of time in a course of weeks to prepare the project and I believe it was a better way of applying our knowledge of the course materials than taking a test to just regurgitate information. In terms of weaknesses of the course, I think there was not really something significant to mention.

At least online, the work was distributed fairly unevenly throughout the week. About 3 hours worth of mini lectures were assigned Monday and due Wednesday morning, the same time as the pset session (which made it difficult to read over the assignment beforehand). Then psets and benchmarks for the project were typically due on Sunday night with a quiz Monday morning.
The quizzes should have been more about the knowledge gained.
I really enjoyed this course. The addition of the final project and the group PSET sessions were very helpful.
The remote setting was not ideal but this course had the best online structure out of most of my courses.

This course gives you every opportunity to succeed. You can tell the professors are rooting for you, not against you. Expectations were very clear, and help was available at every step along the way. 

A weakness in this course is the inconsistency between professors. When I logged on and saw Professor Koelle, I knew that I would understand the material. With Professor Kabeche, I was not so sure.

Strengths: Lots of assistance/peer tutoring if you need help. Lectures are clear and understandable. Not hard to get a good grade in the class as long as you study appropriately.

Weaknesses: There is a large workload, so it's important to stay on top of your work.
Literally love prof Hartman and prof Koelle so much. they made the course so wonderful and fun

Strength: Good communication between the students and instructors. Furthermore, the structure of collaborative learning eliminates internal competition, allowing students to focus solely on learning.

Weakness: A slightly heavy workload and online lectures may sometimes become drawn out/ unengaging. Lectures sometimes are spotty but that's understandable due to individual's WIFI connections.

A major strength of the course was the emphasis on scientific thinking and analysis as opposed to memorization of facts. One weakness was that mini-quizzes had to be completed just two days after the video lectures were released, making for a crammed schedule early in the week.

Though I originally did not enjoy the asynchronous format, in the end it worked quite well for me and was not an issue. The problem sets and discussion sets were productive as well, and the quizzes were completely fair in my opinion. I do think the collaborative PSet sessions could be structured differently, as I felt they sometimes got monopolized by a couple of individuals who had already completed the homework rather than actually being a space to work together.

strengths  very clear assignment guidelines, professors and TFs definitely cared
weaknesses  course was not challenging; definitely feel that adequately prepared students should be allowed to place out of this course

The only weaknesses were largly with Corona restrictions. That being said I feel that the course should have but extra effort into facilitating bonding and study groups with the classmates. I think they may have realized this becuase there is a PSET collab session to meet people in BIO 102

I think that the overall set up of the course was a strength in the sense that the material was reinforced at multiple points throughout a standard class week. I felt as if I was gaining knowledge naturally as the week went on rather than feeling like I had to cram the whole week's material into a weekend's worth of studying. The only weakness of this course, as a result of the online format, was that I found that some of the videos less clearly explored and explained the material than others. That being said however, the mini quizzes, homework, time in section, as well as the benchmark ensured that I understood the material before I was quizzed on it the following Monday.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would certainly recommend this course. It is an amazing course to become accustomed to reading scientific papers and foundational biology.
Absolutely! The course was well taught and I thoroughly enjoyed learning from my professors!

Yes, it provides a strong base in biology and a variety of knowledge. However, the course is advertised to be able to be taken by anyone, even someone who have not taken a biology course before. Even having taken AP Bio, Ive at times felt that class moves extremely fast and its very easy to get lost
Yes, because you gain knowledge on how to apply your knowledge.
Yes! My favorite science course I've taken at Yale so far.
Yes, especially if Professor Koelle is involved! This class is an excellent introduction to biology. It is just challenging enough - not too intimidating or too easy.

Mainly people who take this class take it because it is a pre-req for a major, pre-med track, etc. Therefore, it is not the most exciting class, but the professors are really nice and I enjoyed the class as a whole. Therefore, I would recommend this class to anyone who is willing to put in a little more work, but can still receive an A in the class.
Yes. prof hartman and prof koelle are the best. also it's a pre-med prereq so...
I'd definitely recommend this course. It's a great introduction to both biochemistry/biophysics and scientific thinking in general, and remained stimulating while avoiding any memorization.
Yes-it is a great foundational course in biology and provides great breadth and depth to introduce the subject.
for biology majors, it's a prerequisite
Yes, these people are passionate about what they teach!

Yes, I would. I thoroughly enjoyed the course. The final project was a special highlight. The course was well adapted to online learning and the constraints that that brings. I am very satisfied with the course. Lots of good feedback on everything.

I definitely would recommend this course to another student!! I think that this course was truly a wonderful and effective way to be introduced to biology. It was very manageable and I have finished feeling like I really understand the biological concepts discussed throughout the past six weeks or so.
